Woe. The woe referred to here is the severe anguish and distress pronounced upon Ephraim resulting from God's judgments. Six woes are pronounced in chapters 28 through 33 (28:1; 29:1, 15; 30:1; 31:1; 33:1).

crown of pride. The crown is Samaria, the capital of Ephraim, which is in the Northern Kingdom of Israel. Its walled city stood on a hill, perhaps presenting the image of a crown, and its people were full of pride (see Isa. 9:9). As President Ezra Taft Benson said in our own generation, pride continues to be a great sin on the earth.

drunkards of Ephraim. Ephraim is the name for the Northern Kingdom of Israel, headed by the tribe of Ephraim. Drunkenness is also an accusation made by Isaiah against Samaria (28:1, 3), and Ephraim is singled out for drunkenness in Hosea 7:5, 14. It is not simply literal drunkenness that is being condemned here, however, but spiritual "drunkenness" through sin and apostasy.

whose glorious beauty is a fading flower. Samaria had been a flourishing and glorious community, but its time of glory was about to pass away.

head of the fat valleys. The New International Version reads that Samaria was "set on the head of a fertile valley."
